description: From Middle English thikkenesse, thiknesse, from Old English þicnes (“thickness, viscosity, density, hardness; obscurity, cloud, darkness; thicket; depth, a thick body, anything thick or heavy”), equivalent to thick +‎ -ness. Eclipsed non-native Middle English crassitude (“thickness”)  from Latin crassitūdō (“thickness”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The property of being thick (in dimension).
(uncountable, countable) A measure of how thick (in dimension) something is.
examples: The thickness of the Earth's crust varies from two to 70 kilometres.
Guitar picks come in different thicknesses.
We upholstered the seat with three thicknesses of cloth to make it more comfortable to sit on.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The quality of being thick (in consistency).
examples: Whip the cream until it reaches a good thickness.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, informal) The property of being thick (slow to understand).

verbs.description: thickness (third-person singular simple present thicknesses, present participle thicknessing, simple past and past participle thicknessed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To trim (wood) to a consistent thickness using a thickness planer.
examples: Even if the parts are thicknessed by machine, check for and plane out any cup with a bench plane.
